Toss and cover to keep warm.", "name": "Make the spaghetti", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/spaghetti-marinara-poached-eggs#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bring a pot of water to boil and place a few metal rims from mason jars in the bottom of the pot &#8211; these will act as handy little egg holders. When the water starts boiling, turn the heat off. Quickly (before the water cools off too much) crack individual eggs into a small bowl and pour directly into the metal rim in the boiling water. Repeat for all the eggs. Cover and let the eggs cook on the hot water for 4-5 minutes (4 = very soft, 5 = soft). Carefully remove the eggs from the water with a spatula. Tilt the eggs over the pot to let excess water run off before plating the eggs on your spaghetti.", "name": "Poach the eggs", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/spaghetti-marinara-poached-eggs#instruction-step-3"}], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT20M", "totalTime": "PT30M", "recipeYield": "4", "recipeCategory": "Dinner", "recipeCuisine": "Italian-Inspired", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "9", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "nutrition": {"servingSize": null, "calories": "399 calories", "sugarContent": "7 g", "sodiumContent": "1349 mg", "fatContent": "14.2 g", "saturatedFatContent": "2.9 g", "transFatContent": "0 g", "carbohydrateContent": "51.1 g", "fiberContent": "9.4 g", "proteinContent": "16.6 g", "cholesterolContent": "186 mg", "@type": "nutritionInformation"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Anna"}, "datePublished": "2014-05-18", "reviewBody": "Really well done Lindsay i really like your recipes each time i visit your website :)"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jay"}, "datePublished": "2024-04-24", "reviewBody": "For some reason, the eggs came out hard after just 5 minutes. Drain the water and set aside.\n\u2022 While lentils are cooking, saute the garlic in the olive oil over medium high heat. Add the cabbage, season with salt, and stir fry until the cabbage begins to soften. Remove from heat and set aside.\n\u2022 Add a little more oil to the pan and add the squash. Season with chili powder, cayenne, and salt -- or any seasonings you like. Add the coconut milk and simmer the squash for 8-10 minutes or until soft but not mushy. Add the tom kha paste and stir until mixed in with the coconut milk.\n\u2022 Add the cooked cabbage and lentils to the squash and gently stir to combine. Top each bowl with fresh basil and chopped peanuts.\n\nNOTES:\n\nTom Kha paste is a bright, flavorful Thai product that is usually used to make soup. I bought it at the big grocery store here in Cebu and found it with the curry paste and other spices and pastes. Add the lukewarm milk, egg, and butter. Mix with a bread mixing attachment until moist ingredients are incorporated and mixture is beginning to clump together. Scrape down the sides and add the remaining flour, 1/2 cup at a time, mixing again until dough is sticking together. Use your hands to knead the dough together &#8211; it should be workable and have some elasticity.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/caramel-rolls-with-apples-and-walnuts#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the dough in a large buttered or greased bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Let rest in a warm spot for one hour. When dough has rested for one hour and risen to about double it&#8217;s original size, punch it down and fold the corners back into the middle, making it a compact ball once again. Cover again, with corner side down, and let rest for 30 minutes.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/caramel-rolls-with-apples-and-walnuts#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While dough is rising, saute the apples, butter, sugar, cinnamon, and vanilla together in a saucepan over low heat. Add chopped walnuts and set aside.", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/caramel-rolls-with-apples-and-walnuts#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll the dough into a 9&#215;15 rectangle. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/instant-pot-beef-stew#faq-question-1695750150540", "position": 4, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/instant-pot-beef-stew#faq-question-1695750150540", "name": "How do you thicken this beef stew?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "In this recipe, you\u2019ll cook tapioca pearls right in the stew which will thicken the gravy. However, if you don\u2019t have those on hand, there are other options as well for thickening the stew.<br/><br/>You could toss the beef in 1/3 cup flour, shake off excess, and add to the Instant Pot as normal. If you do this and you have a newer Instant Pot, you will likely need additional liquid (I\u2019ll often do a second can of tomato juice) to avoid the burn warning on the Instant Pot. Or lastly, you could make a slurry of 2 tablespoons cornstarch and 1/4 cup water and add that slurry to everything in the Instant Pot after it\u2019s cooked to thicken things up. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143382802", "position": 2, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143382802", "name": "Do you have to thaw your freezer meals before cooking?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "I am so happy to say that you do NOT need to thaw them first! <strong><em>I don't thaw my freezer recipes before cooking! </em></strong>*evil laugh*\u00a0I just take them straight out of the freezer and put them in the Instant Pot, slow cooker, or oven.<br/><br/>The one exception is the category of <strong>meats in the slow cooker</strong>. Those should always be thawed first. It's a food safety thing - it takes longer amount of time for the meat to heat up in the slow cooker, leaving the frozen meat in the danger zone for a potentially unsafe amount of time.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143399704", "position": 3, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143399704", "name": "How long does it take to thaw frozen meats before cooking?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "If you're making meat in the slow cooker, I recommend thawing them in the fridge for 24 hours first.u003cbr/u003eu003cbr/u003eIf you're using the Instant Pot / pressure cooker, you don't need to thaw the meat first.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143509613", "position": 4, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143509613", "name": "What about thawing and refreezing meat?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "For food safety, I always use freshly purchased, unfrozen meat to assemble the freezer meals.u003cbr/u003eu003cbr/u003eOnce a recipe has been frozen, I don't thaw it out and re-freeze it (remember: I just pull them right out of my freezer and cook them from frozen).u003cbr/u003eu003cbr/u003eAnd once a recipe has been cooked, I don't freeze it again. Most of these recipes make 6 servings so we just keep it in the fridge and eat it up over the next 2-3 days.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143554536", "position": 5, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143554536", "name": "What do these terms mean?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "u003cmeta charset=u0022utf-8u0022/u003eu003cliu003eu003cstrongu003eMirepoix:u003c/strongu003e\u00a0a trio of chopped onions, carrots, and celery.u003c/liu003eu003cbr/u003eu003cliu003eu003cstrongu003eInstant Pot:u003c/strongu003e\u00a0an electric pressure cooker.u003c/liu003eu003cbr/u003eu003cliu003eu003cstrongu003eHigh pressure:u003c/strongu003e\u00a0the setting for the pressure cooker.u003c/liu003eu003cbr/u003eu003cliu003eu003cstrongu003eNatural release:u003c/strongu003e\u00a0letting everything sit in the pressure cooker before opening the valve, rather than opening the valve immediately.u003c/liu003e", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143588669", "position": 6, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143588669", "name": "Can you put something straight from the freezer into the oven?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "When using my Pyrex bakeware, I put them straight from freezer to oven several times (wiping off the extra water or frost on the outside of the container first). It was fine. Nothing shattered.<br/><br/>That being said, I know shattering does happen. I had a pan shatter on me a few years ago, <em>completely unrelated to freezing</em>, and it was slightly traumatic. I would feel really sad to get comments with reports of your shattering glass dishes, so you'll have to decide for yourself what you feel comfortable with.<br/><br/>Here's what the internet says:<br/><br/><a href=\"https://www.pyrexhome.com/product-warranties\">From Pyrex</a>\u00a0<em>(a little unclear)</em><br/><a href=\"https://www.americastestkitchen.com/articles/670-essential-equipment-for-make-ahead-cooking\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">From America's Test Kitchen</a> <em>(they say yes, it's fine)</em><br/><a href=\"https://www.cooksillustrated.com/how_tos/6530-the-perils-of-pyrex\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">From Cooks Illustrated</a>\u00a0<em>(they say no, don't do it)</em><br/><a href=\"https://ask.metafilter.com/102342/Fear-of-Pyrex-shrapnel\">From the people of the internet</a>\u00a0<em>(most say yes, it's fine)</em><br/><br/>If you want to be 100% safe, here are a few alternative things you can do:<br/><br/>Thaw your oven-bound recipes in advance.<br/>Use aluminum pans which will not shatter.<br/>Line your frozen glass containers with parchment so you can pull your lasagnas out and transfer them into a room-temperature pan for baking.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143658268", "position": 7, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143658268", "name": "u003cmeta charset=u0022utf-8u0022/u003eu003cstrongu003eHow do you avoid freezer burn on your freezer meals?\u00a0u003c/strongu003e", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Get all the air out of your storage containers before freezing.u003cbr/u003eu003cbr/u003eI had some mild freezer burn on a few of my recipes because it's hard to press out all the air when using a reusable container like a Pyrex bowl with a lid. To be honest, I didn't think it was all that big of a deal. My belief on this is that the point when freezer burn really starts to become a bad-tasting problem is when it's built up on stuff that's been hanging out in your freezer for, like, months upon months. I wouldn't worry too much about a little layer of frost on top of your soups in your Pyrex containers.u003cbr/u003eu003cbr/u003eIf it's gonna bug you, plastic bags might be a better choice so you can really squeeze the air out.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143691916", "position": 8, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143691916", "name": "u003cmeta charset=u0022utf-8u0022/u003eu003cstrongu003eShould you freeze the liquids with your freezer meals?\u00a0u003c/strongu003e", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Either way will work!u003cbr/u003eu003cbr/u003eI generally u003cstrongu003eDO NOTu003c/strongu003e include the liquids (broth, water, tomato sauce, etc.) because I find it's harder for them to fit in the freezer and then in the slow cooker or Instant Pot. I just add them right before cooking.u003cbr/u003eu003cbr/u003eThat being said, if you do include the liquids in your freezer containers, the nice thing is they'll be COMPLETELY ready to go when you pull them out.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1743189539315", "position": 9, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1743189539315", "name": "What size labels do you use for the printable labels?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "<a href=\"https://amzn.to/2Hh36iB\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener nofollow\">These are the labels you need</a> to print these at home.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143743586", "position": 10, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143743586", "name": "Can you use fresh vegetables in freezer meals?\u00a0", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "A lot of people say no, <em>but I say heck yes!</em><br/><br/><strong>All of these recipes have been tested using fresh AND frozen produce</strong>, including onions, carrots, celery, potatoes (!!), mushrooms, and squash. Personally, I didn't notice a huge difference between fresh or frozen produce (possibly because most of the produce-forward recipes here are soups, and softened veggies never hurt a soup).<br/><br/>Some people swear that you should never use mushrooms or potatoes in freezer meals, but I did it, as did our tester, and neither of us had any issues. Lots of people say that your potatoes will turn black in the freezer, but neither I or our tester experienced that with russet potatoes OR sweet potatoes. The vegetables added great flavor, bulk, and nutrition, so I say yes! Use your fresh OR frozen veggies.<br/>What can I say? I'm a rule breaker.<br/><br/>If you want to go with frozen produce, these are the frozen produce products I have used which save me a lot of time:<br/><br/><a href=\"https://www.target.com/p/frozen-roasted-sweet-potato-chunks-12oz-good-38-gather-8482/-/A-82421190\">Frozen potatoes (pre-cooked)</a><br/>Frozen mushrooms<br/><a href=\"https://www.target.com/p/frozen-butternut-squash-12oz-good-38-gather-8482/-/A-79580699\">Frozen squash</a><br/>Frozen mirepoix*<br/><br/><em>*One thing to note about the frozen mirepoix is that it's usually a little heavier on the onions, so I often add a little extra chopped carrots or celery (simply because I prefer less onion). If you love onions, you're all good.</em>", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143796190", "position": 11, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143796190", "name": "How do you make the freezer meal process as fast and easy as possible?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "<li>You are in the right place! :) Because these recipes are very time-friendly.</li><br/><li>Buy pre-chopped fresh or frozen veggies. Use pre-chopped garlic and onions. This is a huge time-saver. Downside is that it generates more plastic waste and can be slightly more expensive, but it is EXTREMELY efficient!</li><br/><li>Honestly, skip the measuring cups and spoons. <em>Just eyeball it. </em>I rarely measure for my freezer meals. These recipes are all pretty forgiving.</li><br/><li>Don't do too many at a time. I find that 4-6 per prep session takes me about an hour and a half, which is usually my limit for time and energy.</li>", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143842443", "position": 12, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143842443", "name": "Do you need an Instant Pot to make freezer meals?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Here's the thing - if you love the convenience of freezer meals and are not always great at planning ahead (thawing, long cook times, etc.), then YES! I think you would really, really love an <a href=\"https://www.target.com/p/instant-pot-6qt-9-in-1-pressure-cooker-bundle/-/A-90571185\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener nofollow\">Instant Pot</a> <em>(affiliate link)</em> for your freezer meals.<br/><br/>Here's why I ADORE the Instant Pot for freezer meal recipes:<br/><br/>I decide what we're having for dinner at 4pm, pop it out of the freezer and into the Instant Pot, and in have it done before 6pm! That's with <strong>no advance thawing and minimal stress</strong>. You can't do that with the slow cooker and you can rarely do it with the oven. I highly recommend an Instant Pot if you want to take full advantage of the convenience of your freezer meals!<br/><br/><strong><a href=\"https://www.target.com/p/instant-pot-6qt-9-in-1-pressure-cooker-bundle/-/A-90571185\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener nofollow\">Click here to see the Instant Pot</a></strong> that I use <em>(affiliate link)</em>!", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143881081", "position": 13, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/freezer-meals#faq-question-1634143881081", "name": "Are these freezer meals healthy?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes. I consider these freezer meals healthy because they are made with real food. Real food = food that is minimally processed, or single ingredient foods. Vegetables, meats, legumes, and whole grains are examples of real food.<br/><br/><em>Healthy means something different to everyone.</em> For some people, the plant-based recipes will be healthy. For some people, the low calorie recipes will be healthy. For some people, the high protein recipes will be healthy. So the thing I keep coming back to when determining whether or not they are healthy is the inclusion of as many <em><strong>real, whole foods</strong></em> as possible.<br/><br/>A few of these recipes use prepared sauces - for example, a jar of marinara sauce. I normally prefer homemade sauces, but when prepping freezer meals, convenience and efficiency are top priorities which is why I think this is a perfect time to use the store-bought pasta or enchilada sauces. I recommend looking for clean versions of these sauces - avoiding added dyes, added sugars, etc. when possible!", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}]}, {"@context": Soak overnight. This really helps with the texture of the beans, and they won&#8217;t take as long to cook. Place the pork in a large bowl with 2 cups soy sauce, 2 tablespoons brown sugar, garlic, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Cover and marinade in the refrigerator overnight. I left the meat whole for the marinating, but you can also cut it into pieces before marinating.", "name": "The night before", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/crockpot-pork-adobo-with-black-beans#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "drain the beans. Discard the pork marinade, reserving the bay leaves, garlic, and peppercorns. Cut the pork into 2-inch pieces. Place the black beans in the crockpot, cover with the pork, garlic, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Pour 1 1/4 cup soy sauce, 3 cups water, and 2 tablespoons brown sugar over the top. Stir once to get the liquid in and around the beans. Cook in the crockpot on low for 8 hours or high for 5-6 hours.", "name": "The next morning", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/crockpot-pork-adobo-with-black-beans#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "check on the adobo &#8211; the pork should be very tender and some of the pieces might naturally fall apart, there should be enough liquid to keep the whole mixture &#8220;saucy&#8221;, and the beans should be soft. Add the vinegar and cook for another 20-30 minutes. Why?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "This is because of the flour. It\u2019s really important to get the right amount of flour here, which is why I\u2019m going to recommend that you <em>take the time to spoon your flour into your measuring cups and level them with a knife</em>. That is not something I typically recommend because I don\u2019t have the patience for it \u2013 but here, it really does matter! An over-floured cookie will be too thick and won\u2019t get the crispy edge. Watch the video to see the consistency of the dough that we\u2019re going for \u2013 I find that it\u2019s easier to go by the feel than by exact measurements since there are so many variables that can affect how much flour you\u2019ll need. If you're weighing your flour and making the recipe as-is without any scaling, we've found that 335 grams of flour works best. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/browned-butter-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1611194450903", "position": 2, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/browned-butter-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1611194450903", "name": "I measured my butter, but I ended up with less after I browned it. Why?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "If you brown the butter for longer than 5 minutes, it\u2019ll start to lose moisture which will affect your butter\u00a0 / flour ratios. I like to transfer my butter to a glass measuring cup after I brown it to make sure I still have very close to 1 cup of butter. If you have less, it\u2019s fine, they\u2019ll still turn out, you just want to scale back on the flour by 1-2 tablespoons if you lost a little of that moisture.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/browned-butter-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1611194542571", "position": 3, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/browned-butter-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1611194542571", "name": "I see little flecks of brown in my butter. Is that normal?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes! The browned butter will have flecks of brown in it \u2013 those are the browned milk solids and they hold all the yummy flavor, so be sure to really scrape your pan down so you get to use all of them!", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/browned-butter-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1611194607903", "position": 4, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/browned-butter-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1611194607903", "name": "How can I store the dough in the fridge or freezer?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "This makes a very large batch of cookies! If you don\u2019t need all of the cookies at once, here\u2019s what I recommend:\u00a0<em>split the dough into thirds.</em>\u00a0One third of it should fit onto one large cookie sheet, so you can bake that immediately. Then store the other two thirds in their own containers and either refrigerate (up to 5 days) or freeze (up to three months) and you\u2019ve got two more fresh batches sometime in the future! Coat the rice with the curry paste and oil, layer it in clumps on a baking sheet, and bake at 425 for 15 minutes on a rack towards the top of the oven. It'll get a dried, crisped exterior but the inside of the clumps will be chewy and soft. But this version of a crispy rice salad is pretty mild - and if you want it to be more spicy, you can add more chili crisp or throw some chiles in the mix. If you're veg, you can try it and let me know. :) ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/crispy-rice-salad-with-cucumbers-and-herbs#faq-question-1695750150540", "position": 8, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/crispy-rice-salad-with-cucumbers-and-herbs#faq-question-1695750150540", "name": "How can you make crispy rice salad vegetarian?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "The only thing in the salad that is not vegetarian is the fish sauce and (sometimes) the curry paste. I use Thai Kitchen red curry paste which is naturally vegan. For a fish sauce sub, you could try <a href=\"https://thefoodietakesflight.com/vegan-fish-sauce/\">making your own</a> fish sauce. Soy sauce or coconut aminos would also be a possible sub - it wouldn't have the same flavor but would work in a similar way as the salty part of the dressing. You may need to dilute the dressing a bit if it's too strong, depending on your specific soy sauce.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/crispy-rice-salad-with-cucumbers-and-herbs#faq-question-1695750187044", "position": 9, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/crispy-rice-salad-with-cucumbers-and-herbs#faq-question-1695750187044", "name": "Is crispy rice salad gluten-free?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, this recipe is gluten-free. You may want to confirm that your jasmine rice is certified gluten-free as there can be cross-contact contamination, and you may want to also check the label on the fish sauce and the curry paste just to confirm that these are gluten-free as it can vary from brand to bran. But all the other ingredients in the salad are naturally gluten-free. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Chimichurri Shrimp with Rice and Tzatziki", "description": "Saucy, punchy, and delightful Chimichurri Shrimp! Served with a tomato salad, a pile of hot steamy rice, and a dollop of creamy tzatziki.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsay Ostrom", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/about"}, "keywords": "chimichurri, chimichurri shrimp, rice bowl, tomato salad, easy dinner, quick and easy", "image": ["https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Chimichurri-Shrimp-6-225x225.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Chimichurri-Shrimp-6-260x195.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Chimichurri-Shrimp-6-320x180.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Chimichurri-Shrimp-6.jpg"], "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/chimichurri-shrimp-with-tomatoes", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup olive oil", "2 tablespoons red wine vinegar", "1/2 cup parsley", "1 small chile (I use fresno chiles)", "3-4 cloves garlic", "1 teaspoon dried oregano", "1 teaspoon salt", "1 pound jumbo shrimp, raw", "1/2 cup tzatziki, for serving", "2 cups cherry tomatoes, halved, for serving", "bread or rice for serving"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Blitz up your sauce in a food processor. It will be somewhat emulsified and it will settle a bit as it rests. If you don&#8217;t have a food processor, finely chop everything and mix together in a bowl. Divide the sauce into three bowls: one bowl for tossing with the shrimp, one bowl for brushing while cooking, and one bowl for brushing at the table.", "name": "Chimichurri", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/chimichurri-shrimp-with-tomatoes#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Thaw shrimp (if frozen) and remove shells and tails (if necessary or desired). Pat dry with paper towels. Toss the shrimp with one third of the chimichurri.\u00a0", "name": "Get That Flavor on Your Shrimp:\u00a0", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/chimichurri-shrimp-with-tomatoes#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Thread the saucy shrimp onto soaked wood skewers. Transfer to a grill pan, grill, or standard saut\u00e9 pan over medium high heat. Add the shrimp and cook for 2-3 minutes per side, depending on the size of your shrimp. Brush with additional sauce as you cook. It gives a silkiness and a lusciousness that you can't get from the thick, tangy Greek yogurt. Be sure to always measure your flour correctly (spooning it in to the measuring cup vs. scooping from the bag). Since you can always add more, it's important to not over-flour to start with. Roll them up into balls, freeze them on a sheet pan, and then keep them in a bag in the freezer until ready to bake. We'd recommend letting them thaw on a sheet pan (covered) before baking.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/the-best-soft-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1602618026113", "position": 4, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/the-best-soft-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1602618026113", "name": "Can I make these gluten-free?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "We've never tried it with this recipe, but I'm sure you could! We like the fridge method to keep them fresh! <a href=\"https://www.target.com/p/square-glass-food-storage-container-made-by-design-153/-/A-53314588?preselect=53138193#lnk=sametab\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">These</a> are our personal favorite glass storage containers!*", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/the-best-soft-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1657747941358", "position": 6, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/the-best-soft-chocolate-chip-cookies#faq-question-1657747941358", "name": "Does this recipe work for high-altitude baking?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes! Remember that when baking at a high altitude some baked goods will leaven and flatten more quickly. If you're baking at 3,000+ ft elevation, we recommend increasing your oven temp to 375 degrees and reducing bake time by a few minutes. For more information on high-altitude baking, we love u003ca href=u0022https://www.kingarthurbaking.com/learn/resources/high-altitude-bakingu0022 target=u0022_blanku0022 rel=u0022noreferrer noopener nofollowu0022u003ethisu003c/au003e resource.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "The Best Soft Chocolate Chip Cookies", "description": "These are THE BEST soft chocolate chip cookies! I tried it without the egg yolks, and the texture just wasn't the same.<br/><br/>If you're concerned, use pasteurized eggs and/or heat the egg yolk mixture over a double boiler at 140 degrees F for 3-5 minutes.<br/><br/>If you're pregnant or immunocompromised, just skip the yolks, the recipe will still work without them. Add dulce de leche, mix again, and add a pinch of salt to taste.\u00a0", "name": "Mix Bowl 2", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/dulce-de-leche-tiramisu#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Fold whipped cream into the egg and mascarpone mixture. Use a fine mesh strainer to dust the bottom of your pan with cocoa powder. This helps absorb excess moisture from the espresso so it doesn&#8217;t get too wet.", "name": "Pan Prep", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/dulce-de-leche-tiramisu#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dip ladyfingers very briefly in the espresso; turn to coat (I give a slow count of 3 while flipping each one &#8211; back side, front side, back side again and remove). You don&#8217;t want these in the espresso for a very long time or the whole thing will fall apart. Ladyfingers should cover the bottom of the pan. Layer half the creamy mixture on top of the ladyfingers; repeat ladyfingers layer, then finish with the rest of the creamy layer. I say that because it annoys me a little when cooking blogs state \"35 min total time,\" but really it takes at least an hour for most people.  Perhaps it is on me because I do not have a dishwasher or someone to help with prep, etc., but that's real life for a lot of us. \r\n\r\nI reiterate, not a kitchen novice. So, when I read this recipe calling for \"2 c. quinoa,\" I assume that means dry. I may be wrong, but I believe that's the standard way of writing a recipe. The included instructions for cooking it confirm that assumption. I point this out because the recipe says it yield 5 - 1 c. servings. 2 c. of dry quinoa yields 7.5 c. (or at least mine did), so it's already 1.5 c. per serving not including the meat, eggs, &amp; beans. The \"filling\" (I mixed the meat, beans, and eggs) was 5 c. so maybe that is what it is referring too? However, when the whole stack is put together, it is 2.5 c. ea for 5 servings. \r\n\r\nSorry, I hope that doesn't come across as a grumpy complainer because I really meant it to be constructive. Now that's out of the way...\r\n\r\nThanks for this great recipe! I will be adding it to my regular rotation. I meal prep, and breakfast recipes are the biggest struggle! I used ground pork sausage b/c we raise our own so that's what I had. 2 tbsp. adobo ole spice blend (probably could have used just a bit more). I left out the salt originally b/c there's a lot in that spice blend but had to add it at the end. I mixed the meat, eggs, &amp; beans together. I put 1.5 c. quinoa &amp; 1 c. meat mixture per bowl then added just under 1 oz. pepperjack cheese to each. I think next time I'll reduce the quinoa to 1 c. / bowl because I went from starving to stuffed. \r\n\r\nAlthough I thought it was delicious, I felt like it needed just a little something that I couldn't put my finger on. Place the sliced leeks in a bowl of water. Gently massage and break them apart so that any dirt trapped between the layers gets released. Let the dirt settle and then pull the leeks out of the bowl, discarding the water. Repeat as many times as necessary to get them clean. (My 3 year old daughter loves to help with this! Yes I was dealing with 3 kids at the time, but cooking the bacon alone took 15 minutes, much less actually cutting all the english muffins, assembling everything, etc. For me including egg baking time, it was a solid hour at least. I'm an average speed cook and not as efficient as I could be, but just being realistic! :) \r\n-I did pre-toast my english muffins (which I actually didn't include in the above time, I know that's not required)\r\n-I had one sandwich fresh, with avocado and sriracha and found the egg a bit thin for my liking, so I did end up adding a bit more to the other sandwiches, using all of the leftover parts from the pan.\r\n-I put the sandwich directly from the freezer to the oven and after 20 minutes (wrapped still) it was still frozen on the inside. After opening the foil for 15 more minutes, it was hot. I will try putting in the fridge first overnight, was just worried about it getting soggy. If you're reheating from frozen, I think at least 30 minutes and definitely will need to open the foil up for a bit.\r\n-The reheated in the oven sandwich was still awesome, almost as good as fresh!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Linger"}, "datePublished": "2019-03-11", "reviewBody": "What a fabulous idea!! When it&#8217;s all well-mixed, roll into smallish meatballs. (If you find the mixture is too wet to handle, you can add a bit of panko or a tablespoon of cornstarch to help them hold a bit more. But don&#8217;t panic &#8211; wet is normal for this mixture. Through all my tastings, I have developed my preferences for them over the years. And my version here leans slightly thicker through the middle, just enough to really give you a satisfying bite, but the pancakes themselves are still thin, flexible, and have that signature lacy edge. For a traditionally super-thin Swedish pancake recipe, check out <a href=\"https://true-north-kitchen.com/swedish-pancakes-with-lingonberries/\">this recipe</a> from a fellow Minnesotan and Scandinavian baker.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/swedish-pancakes#faq-question-1696819012203", "position": 2, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/swedish-pancakes#faq-question-1696819012203", "name": "How are Swedish pancakes different from regular pancakes?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "The main difference is that Swedish pancakes are thinner and less fluffy. Regular pancakes are fluffy thanks to baking powder or baking soda giving them lift; Swedish pancakes, while thin, have a dense, egg-heavy batter with no baking powder or baking soda. They are more flat, more chewy, and less absorbent of whatever toppings you put on them.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/swedish-pancakes#faq-question-1696819020786", "position": 3, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/swedish-pancakes#faq-question-1696819020786", "name": "How are Swedish pancakes different from crepes?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "The batter of Swedish pancakes and crepes is, from what I can tell, very similar. The most obvious difference is that crepes are made with a crepe roller and often have savory fillings. Swedish pancakes are made with a pan tilt to make them thin and they are almost always served with sweet fillings (lingonberries and cream, be still my heart).", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/swedish-pancakes#faq-question-1696819481710", "position": 4, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/swedish-pancakes#faq-question-1696819481710", "name": "Where do I get lingonberry jam?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "So glad you asked! My kids are obsessed, and I love that they\u2019re high protein and relatively low sugar, Nutella aside. \r\nMy only advice for other first timers is to make sure the pan is nice and hot, don\u2019t try to double the recipe in a standard blender (it doesn\u2019t fit\u2014just make the second batch during the cook time), and don\u2019t wait until your kids are starving or you\u2019ll probably just have kids double fisting handful of chocolate my Swedish joy."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Thiago Trivelato"}, "datePublished": "2023-10-11", "reviewBody": "Thank you very much this content was very helpful"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "1"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "C"}, "datePublished": "2023-10-14", "reviewBody": "It\u2019s \u201dpannkakor\u201d, not \u201dpankakkor\u201d. Finally, lingonberry jam is pretty much the only jam we don\u2019t put on pancakes. It\u2019s tart and goes better with foodies fish/meat/veggie dishes. How else could I make the chicken?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You can make the chicken in the same pan as the sauce! Before you start the sauce, coat the chicken in spices and pan-fry it until it's golden on both sides and cooked all the way through. Remove it, set aside, make the sauce, and then add the chicken back in. The reason I prefer the air fryer chicken is because: 1) I'm able to get a more consistently delicious result - juicy on the inside, golden on the outside every single time - never dry, never overcooked, whereas I find it's easy to over-cook the chicken when pan-frying. And 2) the chicken can cook in the air fryer while I'm simmering the sauce so it goes a bit faster. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/marry-me-chicken#faq-question-1710263822340", "position": 2, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/marry-me-chicken#faq-question-1710263822340", "name": "Can I use sun-dried tomatoes instead of petite diced canned tomatoes?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes - traditionally, Marry Me Chicken recipes use sun-dried tomatoes. I prefer the juiciness of a \"fresh\" tomato - real, actual fresh tomatoes would be ideal but in winter times, a can of petite diced tomatoes is a pretty great stand-in. I would NOT use regular diced canned tomatoes as they are larger and more chunky - the petite dice is important in getting everything just right. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/marry-me-chicken#faq-question-1710263907542", "position": 3, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/marry-me-chicken#faq-question-1710263907542", "name": "What should I use if I can't find petite diced canned tomatoes?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Use sun-dried tomatoes, or fresh tomatoes that have been finely diced and drained of excess juices. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/marry-me-chicken#faq-question-1695750073466", "position": 4, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/marry-me-chicken#faq-question-1695750073466", "name": "What should I serve this chicken with?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "This chicken is perfect with <a href=\"https://pinchofyum.com/instant-pot-mashed-potatoes\">mashed potatoes</a> and a <a href=\"https://pinchofyum.com/simple-green-salad\">side salad</a>. The issue is that you wouldn't get the textured, golden exterior on the chicken which provides such a nice contrast to the creamy sauce. You could do it, yes. (YUM.) This is how I always do it. But if you're in a hurry or just don't feel like the sauce is thickening the way you want it to, whisk 1-2 teaspoons of cornstarch into 1-2 teaspoons of cold water and add it to the simmering sauce. It should give it just enough body and thickness to coat the chicken better. It's not as spicy as a paste and works well as a table sauce, or mixed into another sauce (like this one right here)! It's a bit on the sweet side, but it's not overly spicy. I find 2 tablespoons is the right amount for us but you may want more or less. Currently, the brand is owned by CJ CheilJedang Corporation which is a South Korean international food company based in Seoul, and - lucky for us - their products are widely available at many US grocers. Awesome as a meal or a side!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsay Ostrom", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/about"}, "keywords": "fettuccine recipe, corn pasta, healthy pasta recipe", "image": ["https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/corn-fettuccine-4-225x225.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/corn-fettuccine-4-260x195.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/corn-fettuccine-4-320x180.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/corn-fettuccine-4.jpg"], "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/healthy-chipotle-sweet-corn-fettuccine", "recipeIngredient": ["4-6 ears of fresh sweet corn", "1 lb. uncooked fettuccine noodles", "3 tablespoons salted butter", "1 teaspoon garlic", "1/4 cup flour", "1 cup milk", "1/2 cup half and half", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup water (the stuff that you boiled the corn in is best)", "1/2 cup Greek yogurt &#8211; I used Chobani plain low fat", "1 single chipotle pepper in adobo sauce, minced", "cilantro for serving"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "bring a large pot of water to boil. Place the ears of sweet corn in the pot, cover, and remove from heat. Let the ears &#8220;cook&#8221; for a few minutes before taking them out and letting them cool. (This helps partially cook the corn so it&#8217;s not so raw, but this step is optional.)", "name": "Corn", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/healthy-chipotle-sweet-corn-fettuccine#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cut the corn off the ears. Place the corn kernels in a large nonstick skillet over medium high heat with no oil or butter. Let the corn sit for a few minutes with stirring. Stir once, and let it sit again so that the outside of the corn gets roasty-looking. When the corn is as browned as you want it, remove from the heat.", "name": "Corn", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/healthy-chipotle-sweet-corn-fettuccine#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cook the pasta according to package direction. Keep a little bit of the pasta water.", "name": "Pasta", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/healthy-chipotle-sweet-corn-fettuccine#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the butter in a small saucepan over medium low heat. Add the garlic and saute until soft and fragrant, about 2 minutes. Don&#8217;t burn the garlic &#8211; it will taste bad. Add the flour and stir for 1 minute. Whisk in the milk, half and half, salt, and corn water until the sauce is smooth. Finally stir in the Greek yogurt and the chipotle pepper. Combine the sauce, pasta, and corn in one large pot. Add extra Greek yogurt or pasta water to get the desired consistency for your sauce. Sprinkle with cilantro for serving. Fill the pan with water so it&#8217;s a few inches deep &#8211; enough to touch the squash but not cover it completely. Wrap the whole thing with tinfoil and bake at 350 degrees until fork-tender, about an hour. Remove squash from pan and set aside to cool slightly. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://pinchofyum.com/instant-pot-chicken-and-dumplings#faq-question-1729282421285", "position": 5, "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/instant-pot-chicken-and-dumplings#faq-question-1729282421285", "name": "Can you make this recipe on the stovetop?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, you can! Heat the olive oil in a Dutch oven over medium heat. Add in the mirepoix and saut\u00e9 for a few minutes until softened. Stir in the garlic and potato. Add in the chicken thighs, poultry seasoning, salt, and pepper. Give everything a good stir. Add in the chicken broth. Bring to a simmer, cover the pot, and cook on low for 15 minutes. Then, add in the biscuit pieces. Add additional broth or water to the pot if the mixture seems extra thick. Cover the pot, and simmer for another 15 minutes. Pull out chicken to shred or chop. Then used 4 cups of chicken broth. I cooked it for 9 minutes and the 10ish minutes pressure release. The chicken came out incredibly tender. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Chicken and Rice Casserole", "description": "This chicken and rice casserole is frequently requested by my husband who grew up calling it \"Forgotten Chicken.\" Simple and satisfying!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsay Ostrom", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/about"}, "keywords": "chicken and rice casserole, chicken casserole, rice casserole, casserole recipe", "image": ["https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/chicken-and-rice-casserole-4-225x225.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/chicken-and-rice-casserole-4-260x195.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/chicken-and-rice-casserole-4-320x180.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/chicken-and-rice-casserole-4.jpg"], "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/chicken-and-rice-casserole", "recipeIngredient": ["2 1/2 cups chicken broth (I used 2 cans)", "1 1/2 cups milk", "3/4 cup flour", "1 tablespoon seasoning mix (or 1/2 tsp. onion powder, 1/2 tsp. garlic powder, 1 tsp. salt, 1/2 tsp. pepper, 1/2 tsp. parsley)", "1 \u00bd cups uncooked brown rice, rinsed", "2 tablespoons seasoning mix of your choice for the flavor of the casserole \u2013 my favorite was a smoked hickory southwestern seasoning", "1 cup water", "1 lb. boneless skinless chicken breasts"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "combine the chicken broth and 1/2 cup of the milk in a large saucepan. Bring to a low boil. Meanwhile, in a small bowl, whisk the flour and seasonings into the milk until a smooth, thick mixture forms. Pour the flour and milk mixture into the saucepan over low heat and stir continuously, whisking as the mixture simmers. Continue to simmer and stir/whisk until the mixture is smooth and thick, 5-10 minutes.", "name": "Make the sauce", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/chicken-and-rice-casserole#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Pour into prepared dish.", "name": "Combine Sauce and Rice", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/chicken-and-rice-casserole#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange chicken pieces over the top and sprinkle with the remaining tablespoon of seasoning.", "name": "Add Chicken", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/chicken-and-rice-casserole#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover with aluminum foil and bake for about 45 minutes. Remove foil; bake for an additional 30-45 minutes or until rice and chicken are cooked through and top is slightly browned. Allow to cool for 15 minutes; shred chicken into small pieces and stir to combine with the rice. When the apples have softened a little bit, pour a scoop of pancake batter over the center and let it spread out just to the edges of the apples. Wait a few minutes until you see bubbles rising and the bottom looks dry. Use a spatula to carefully flip the pancakes &#8211; cook another few minutes on the back side until cooked through. Serve warm with maple syrup, chopped pecans, a dusting of powdered sugar. Didn't use an air fryer because I don't have the patience to make them in batches, but they turned out great in the oven. What should I do?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "This happens to me every once in a while (due to variances in temperature of the room or temperature of ingredients). I find that it's almost always because the dough is not warm enough yet. Assuming that your yeast was alive and you are smelling that sweet, yeasty smell from the dough, it just needs a bit more time, warmth, and moisture. Covering it with a damp towel and placing it near a warm oven for an extra 30-60 minutes should get it going. You can also try any of the tricks in\u00a0<a href=\"https://www.tasteofhome.com/article/9-reasons-your-bread-isnt-rising-and-what-to-do-about-it/\">this post</a>- in particular I like the boiling water / oven method.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "House Favorite Cinnamon Rolls with Cream Cheese Frosting", "description": "Our House Favorite Cinnamon Rolls - the ones we make every year! With pillowy brioche dough and cream cheese frosting tucked into every bite.\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsay Ostrom", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/about"}, "keywords": "cinnamon rolls, maple glaze, homemade cinnamon rolls", "image": ["https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Cinnamon-Rolls-Square-1-225x225.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Cinnamon-Rolls-Square-1-260x195.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Cinnamon-Rolls-Square-1-320x180.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Cinnamon-Rolls-Square-1.jpg"], "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 cup lukewarm water (not hot water)", "1 teaspoon instant yeast", "1 teaspoon kosher salt", "1/2 cup butter, melted", "2 eggs", "3 tablespoons honey", "2 1/2 cups flour\u00a0+ extra for dusting", "3 tablespoons butter, melted", "5 tablespoons white sugar", "5 tablespoons brown sugar", "1 teaspoon cinnamon", "2 ounces cream cheese, softened", "2 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened", "1/3 cup powdered sugar", "2 tablespoons milk (more as needed)\u00a0", "1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract", "small pinch of salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Start by adding the water and yeast to a bowl. Melt the butter, whisk in the honey, then the egg and salt. Add your butter mixture to the bowl, and then measure in the flour. Mix with a wooden spoon until combined. It will be messy, sticky, and loose &#8211; that is correct.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover loosely with plastic wrap or a damp towel, and let her rest at room temperature for 1-2 hours until the dough ball has puffed up and roughly doubled in size. I often turn on my oven to 200 degrees and place the dough bowl in close proximity to the fan to speed this process up.", "name": "First rise", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once the dough has doubled in size, gently reach in with your hand and pull the sticky dough from the edges of the bowl. This should somewhat deflate the dough &#8211; that&#8217;s great. Put the bowl in the fridge, covered with plastic wrap. It needs at least 3 hours in the fridge so the dough has time to chill and become easier to handle. Don&#8217;t try to work with it right after the first rise &#8211; chilling is necessary to make it workable. The dough can stay in the fridge for up to 5 days.", "name": "Store in the fridge", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Remove the dough from the fridge and coat the outside lightly with flour. Roll your dough ball out to about a 9&#215;13 rectangle.\u00a0This dough doesn&#8217;t like to be over-handled, and you don&#8217;t want to have to add a lot of extra flour &#8211; so work with it right out of the fridge.", "name": "Assemble the rolls", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Brush the rectangle with the melted butter and sprinkle with the sugars and cinnamon. You can use your hands to press it in and make sure it\u2019s all evenly coated.\u00a0", "name": "Filling", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Roll the dough up starting at the short side. Try not to over-handle the dough as it will become sticky. Once the log is rolled up, use floss or a very sharp knife to trim the uneven ends, and then cut the log into 8 equal rolls. Place the rolls in a 9-10 inch round baking dish or pie plate (another size could also work, I just like how they fit in a round pan with 7 around the outside and one in the center).", "name": "Roll", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 200 degrees and then turn it off.\u00a0Cover the pan loosely with plastic wrap or a damp towel and let the rolls rest in the turned-off oven for 45 minutes. They should fit a little more snugly together in the pan at this point. Cute! Take them out and turn the oven back on to 350 degrees. Bake at 350 degrees for 20-22 minutes.", "name": "Second rise:\u00a0", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use an electric mixer to beat the cream cheese and butter until smooth and creamy. Mix in the powdered sugar, vanilla, and a little bit of milk at a time until you get a smooth glaze; then continue to beat with the electric mixer until you have a light and fluffy frosting.", "name": "Prep the cream cheese frosting", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/cinnamon-rolls#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When they come out of the oven, give them a minute to cool. Vegetarian / vegan.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Lindsay Ostrom", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/about"}, "keywords": "homemade ramen, spicy ramen, tofu recipe", "image": ["https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Ramen-Recipe-225x225.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Ramen-Recipe-260x195.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Ramen-Recipe-320x180.jpg", "https://pinchofyum.com/wp-content/uploads/Ramen-Recipe.jpg"], "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/homemade-spicy-ramen-with-tofu", "recipeIngredient": ["1 small yellow onion", "1/2 cup red miso", "1/2 cup white miso", "3 tablespoons sambal oelek", "6 cloves garlic", "2-inch piece fresh ginger", "3 tablespoons mirin", "2 tablespoons vegetable oil", "1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil", "12-15 ounces extra-firm tofu", "1 tablespoon oil", "4 eggs", "5 ounces fresh shiitake mushrooms, chopped (but see notes about dried mushrooms!)", "3-4 cups vegetable or chicken stock", "2 cups plain unsweetened soy milk", "6 ounces ramen noodles", "scallions, roasted seaweed, sesame oil for serving"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pulse all miso paste ingredients together in a food processor until a smooth, thick paste forms. You will use about half of it for this recipe and the other half can be frozen or refrigerated for a few days.", "name": "Make Miso Paste", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/homemade-spicy-ramen-with-tofu#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Press as much moisture as you can out of the tofu using paper towels or a tofu press. Cut into cubes. In a large pot, heat the oil on medium high heat and start frying the tofu. Once the tofu has browned, add 1/4 cup of the spicy miso paste and cook for another minute or two to get a nice golden color. Remove from pan and set aside.", "name": "Cook Tofu", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/homemade-spicy-ramen-with-tofu#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(See notes about dried mushrooms if using) To the same pan, add the chopped shiitake and a tablespoon or so of miso paste and stir fry until golden brown. Add the stock and soy milk and bring to a simmer. Place 1/2 cup spicy miso paste on top of a very fine sieve. Lower the sieve half-way into the simmering soup and use a spoon to slowly dissolve the paste into the soup. Discard the \u201csolids\u201d remaining in the sieve and let the soup simmer for another 5 minutes. Taste and adjust seasoning &#8211; add salt or a little soy sauce until it tastes like a spicy ramen broth.", "name": "Make Broth", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/homemade-spicy-ramen-with-tofu#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cook the ramen noodles according to package instructions and drain well. While the ramen is cooking, bring a small pot of water to boil. When it reaches boiling, add 4 eggs and reduce heat to the lowest possible setting. Cook for exactly 7 minutes, remove eggs from water, run under cold water, and let them set for a few minutes. Peel shells off carefully. Heat the oil over medium heat. Drop a small bit of batter in the oil to test it &#8211; when it rises to the top and bubbles, the oil is ready. Dip cauliflower florets in the batter and let the excess drip off before gently setting in the oil. Fry for a few minutes on each side, then flip, repeating sides several times if necessary until you get a nice golden brown fried exterior. The additional frying time helps make it a little crunchier, which I very much like. \ud83d\ude42 Remove and set on a cooling rack with paper towels underneath (again, rather than putting it all on a plate or bowl with paper towels, this keeps it crispy vs. soggy).", "name": "Cauliflower Frying", "url": "https://pinchofyum.com/general-tsos-cauliflower#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Toss the fried cauliflower with the sauce (enough just to cover) and sprinkle with scallions and sesame seeds for serving.
